WorkItem.ClosedComment: Closing these issues as they are basically invalidated by Cataclysm mechanic changes
WorkItem.Description: The tooltip for Blade Ward (http://www.wowhead.com/?spell=64441) indicates that it does 600-800 damage on a parry after it has procced.  However, the list of main hand enchants in rawr for prot warriors is broken down by Survival, Mitigation, and Threat.  In this list, Blade Ward's value is shown to be exclusively due to its increased Mitigation (avoidance, really).  Since Blade Ward does damage, damage is threat, and there is no indication from rawr that Blade Ward adds any threat, this leads me to believe that Blade Ward is not modeled correctly.  What am I missing here?
WorkItem.Summary: [ProtWarr] Blade Ward enchant not modeled correctly

Comments.Message: That all sounds correct. However, just to play devil's advocate, can anyone test if the Blade Ward damage proc actually does threat? Many reactive abilities (such as Thorns) do not.
TECHNICALLY, Parry inherently has a threat component, so should be showing SOME sort of threat (hasted melee attack speed upon Parry, given the timing condition).

As an aside, I tested Thorns last night and its damage does provide threat for the person it is cast on, about 1/3 of the damage it does if memory serves.

I'll try to get and test Blade Ward tonight and report my results.
Tested and confirmed to cause threat.  Blade Ward proc'd for 727 damage, and it caused 727 threat.
Curious about the Thorns test you did. Perhaps talents or spellpower are related? I tested it with no talents and no spellpower, putting it on a priest, and it did no threat.

Perhaps you're right about spellpower.  I took thorns from a restoration druid.  It caused her to gain 138 threat to cast the spell on me, and every time the mob hit me, it took 172-173 damage, and I gained 172-173 threat.
Nope, nevermind, just tested it again explicitly, it did generate threat.
Suppose we can do this with our new damage proc stuff... will look into it.
